question.title: How to dynamically load a Java class without using a class loader?

node.contents: Actually where I read that was in a pdf that one their employees (trying to convince me to use/buy the product) sent to me, but it can also be found in: http://www.slideshare.net/boothdavid/how-can-jrebel-save-me-6-weeks-of-builds-and-redeploys-this-year in slide number 8, I will also try to add a screenshot of the pdf I have

node.contents: double check the quote, they might have written their own implementation and kinda glossed over that.. "we don't use the jre class loader"

node.contents: I recently saw an online presentation of JRebel in which they explain what their product does, in one of the slides they mention they don't use class loaders (see screenshot below).

astNode.text: I recently saw an online presentation of JRebel in which they explain what their product does, in one of the slides they mention they don't use class loaders (see screenshot below).

node.contents: I have some projects in which I use class loaders for dynamically loading classes at runtime, for example for dependency injection (like in the Maker Factory framework that I developed). I thought the only way to load a class in Java was by using a class loader.

astNode.text: I have some projects in which I use class loaders for dynamically loading classes at runtime, for example for dependency injection (like in the Maker Factory framework that I developed). I thought the only way to load a class in Java was by using a class loader.

node.contents: It uses the existing classloaders, of course. Otherwise, how would a Java application even execute :)

astNode.text: It uses the existing classloaders, of course. Otherwise, how would a Java application even execute :)

node.contents: ha right, so the answer to "How to dynamically load a Java class without using a class loader?" is "You can't, but you can ...". Which is cool, just wanted to clarify

astNode.text: ha right, so the answer to "How to dynamically load a Java class without using a class loader?" is "You can't, but you can ...". Which is cool, just wanted to clarify

node.contents: so it does use a classloader?

astNode.text: so it does use a classloader?

node.contents: Disclaimer: I'm involved with JRebel development

astNode.text: Disclaimer: I'm involved with JRebel development

node.contents: Technically, it is possible to bypass the classloader with some Unsafe magic, and JVM leverages that with lambdas when creating the runtime anonymous classes (in Java 8).

astNode.text: Technically, it is possible to bypass the classloader with some Unsafe magic, and JVM leverages that with lambdas when creating the runtime anonymous classes (in Java 8).

node.contents: However, JRebel actually integrates with the existing classloaders and doesn't create new ones - that's what the slide mean. JRebel doesn't drop the existing classloader when it has to reload a class. Instead, it loads and versions the classes within the existing classloaders.

astNode.text: However, JRebel actually integrates with the existing classloaders and doesn't create new ones - that's what the slide mean. JRebel doesn't drop the existing classloader when it has to reload a class. Instead, it loads and versions the classes within the existing classloaders.

node.contents: So the answer to this question may be: There is no way to dynamically load a Java class without using a class loader for the first time. But it is possible to reload a class partially by instrumenting the class loader.

astNode.text: So the answer to this question may be: There is no way to dynamically load a Java class without using a class loader for the first time. But it is possible to reload a class partially by instrumenting the class loader.

node.contents: Based on Dave Newton's answer link, extracting the important things from the JRebel faq:

astNode.text: Based on Dave Newton's answer link, extracting the important things from the JRebel faq:

node.contents: They use the Instrumentation API to instrument the Container/Server class loaders, that way they can dynamically monitor and control the loading process. They will scan the class-path in search of the .class file that corresponds to the loaded class and use the file timestamp to detect changes on it. When a change is detected they will propagate that change through the instrumented class loader. It will preserve the existing instances of the class but won't re-run the constructor, which means that new added fields won't be initialized.

astNode.text: They use the Instrumentation API to instrument the Container/Server class loaders, that way they can dynamically monitor and control the loading process. They will scan the class-path in search of the .class file that corresponds to the loaded class and use the file timestamp to detect changes on it. When a change is detected they will propagate that change through the instrumented class loader. It will preserve the existing instances of the class but won't re-run the constructor, which means that new added fields won't be initialized.

node.contents: Indeed, the only way to load a class is through a class loader.

astNode.text: Indeed, the only way to load a class is through a class loader.

node.contents: The JRebel folks probably meant to say that the don't use class loaders to redefine classes. Redefining a class is possible through other means, for instance through JVMTI.

astNode.text: The JRebel folks probably meant to say that the don't use class loaders to redefine classes. Redefining a class is possible through other means, for instance through JVMTI.

node.contents: You can of course read the class file into memory yourself. But to make the class available in your code, you still need to use ClassLoader#defineClass.

astNode.text: You can of course read the class file into memory yourself. But to make the class available in your code, you still need to use ClassLoader#defineClass.

node.contents: In general, any class that is used in a program must have been defined by a class loader, otherwise what should getClass().getClassLoader() return?

astNode.text: In general, any class that is used in a program must have been defined by a class loader, otherwise what should getClass().getClassLoader() return?

node.contents: they mention they don't use class loaders.

astNode.text: they mention they don't use class loaders.

node.contents: Every class uses a ClassLoader (except primitives). However, a library doesn't have to create additional ClassLoader.

astNode.text: Every class uses a ClassLoader (except primitives). However, a library doesn't have to create additional ClassLoader.

node.contents: Even a "Hello World" program will have two class loaders (one for boostrapping)

astNode.text: Even a "Hello World" program will have two class loaders (one for boostrapping)

node.contents: I thought the only way to load a class in Java was by using a class loader.

astNode.text: I thought the only way to load a class in Java was by using a class loader.

node.contents: It is, but you can force the existing classloader to load your class which is hack but might be simpler to use.

astNode.text: It is, but you can force the existing classloader to load your class which is hack but might be simpler to use.

node.contents: (Correction) If you use null as a ClassLoader, Unsafe.defineClass() will default to the ClassLoader of the caller.

astNode.text: (Correction) If you use null as a ClassLoader, Unsafe.defineClass() will default to the ClassLoader of the caller.

node.contents: They don't use any new classloaders; they extend the default ones.

astNode.text: They don't use any new classloaders; they extend the default ones.
